Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Modern Numerical Matrix Methods for Network and Graph Computations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Connected data is a hallmark of the Internet age. We now have an unprecedented ability to collect information i) on social relationships from websites like Facebook; ii) on connections between ideas from hyperlinked repositories such as Wikipedia; iii) on links between scientific fields from online cross-referenced citation databases; iv) on interactions between proteins in biology; and v) even on the connections in the human brain. Network computations, such as finding the most important people, ideas, papers, or the most important connections, help refine these raw collections of information into meaningful summaries. Consequently, making these computations fast and efficient will help produce scientific insights from the growing plethora of data available.

A highly successful paradigm for stating network computations is as the solution of a matrix problem. For instance, such an approach was the heart of Google's celebrated PageRank algorithm for finding the most important pages on the web. Modern connected data, however, is so large that it has eclipsed the ability of even the best algorithms from the 20th century to cope. Interesting network computations have become more complicated as well. The investigator will study a new class of algorithms to compute nonlinear functions of matrices, such as the matrix exponential. The matrix exponential has many uses; for example, it underlies many new computations designed to identify the most important relationships in neural networks. Standard techniques for the matrix exponential involve examining all of the connections at each step (and there could be hundreds or thousands of steps), only to highlight a few pieces of information. A more recent paradigm, called local computations, only utilizes the connections from a few entities (in the matrix, they only look at a few rows or columns) at a time. The goal of this research is to design new algorithms for the matrix exponential and other functions of matrices in the local computations paradigm. These new algorithms will be able to operate on the world's largest networks quickly (ideally in seconds or minutes), and help application specialists study their data in new ways. Three driving applications will be ranking and voting, link prediction, and brain networks. The investigation will also include the study of higher-order connections in networks that give rise to three or four dimensional matrices -- commonly called tensors.

All of the software developed for this research will be made available in a software package for local computations of matrix functions. The investigator will present tutorials on this software package to ensure that researchers across many disciplines can utilize the outcome of this research. To ensure that this research reaches students across many disciplines, the investigator will develop a graduate course on the use of matrix methods for network computations. Finally, given the growing importance of network data, the investigator will develop a module for high school students to show how solving systems of equations, part of the core high school curriculum, can be used to analyze information networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are a wide variety of complex systems of interacting entities that people in society engage with on a daily basis. Examples include social networks such as Twitter and Facebook, infrastructure networks such as the set of flights that connect airports, and energy distribution networks that provide electricity. When scientists, engineers, and researchers study these systems, they commonly use something called a mathematical network or graph. A mathematical network or graph is a simplified representation that usually focuses only on the connections among the entities. The major intellectual merit of the work conducted under this research project is a new set of methods to analyze these complex systems as mathematical networks or graphs.

One of the most important analyses on networks is called a diffusion. This term emerges from the physics of how water spreads over a surface or how a smell dissipates through the air. The same physics abstractions also apply to a network. The result of a network diffusion is described by a set of linear or nonlinear equations that need to be solved. Prior to this research, most algorithms to solve these diffusions needed to look at the entire network, even when the diffusion started with a single point in a vast network. 

Simply put, the idea underlying this project is that the result of the diffusion is often going to concentrate on only a small part of the network, yet the existing algorithms needed to computationally manipulate information associated with every part of the network. To use a water analogy, if we think of a network as a table, and a diffusion as water spreading, then previous methods would need to look at the entire table to decide where a drop of water will settle -- even when the drop would only touch a small part of a large table. This project produced a comprehensive new set of methods that enable diffusions to run on networks and only manipulate pieces where the diffusion concentrates.  In the water analogy, our new software and algorithms only find where the water spreads on a table, without ever seeing the entire table. 

The result and impact of these studies is that we can run algorithms to analyze networks that are many orders of magnitude larger than previously possible. For instance, we can study a 2010 snapshot of the Twitter network with billions of connections in a few hundred milliseconds on a simple laptop computer. 

In addition, we developed entirely new classes of diffusions that explore more complicated interaction patterns in the network. For instance, the standard representation of a network involves only pairwise interactions between entities. Our research created a new type of analysis based on a small pattern of interactions. Among other uses, this research showed the importance of competition for a food source, which is an interaction involving three species, in characterizing an ecosystem. 

The broader impact of our work includes training a number of PhD students, undergraduate students, and high-school students. The PI funded one student through an entire PhD with this project in addition to partially supporting four others at various stages of their degrees. The project funded five separate undergraduate students and one high-school student for at least a semester of work on the project. We developed lectures for a broad group on a simple introduction to network-based modeling and diffusions. We developed software to collect and work with data on pairwise and triplet ranking in networks and use that data in classrooms. We also produced freely available software to implement our methods and ideas that are being used as a benchmark by others.
